title: Paua industry welcomes extension of shell fishery closure along Kaikoura coast
text:
Paua industry welcomes extension of shell fishery closure along Kaikoura coast EMMA DANGERFIELD Last updated 15:03, February 20 2017 SUPPLIED 
Jason Ruawai is chairman of PauaMAC3, the representative body for professional paua divers in Canterbury. 
Paua stocks along the Kaikoura coast will be given more time to replenish as an emergency closure of the fishery is extended. 
Primary Industries Minister Nathan Guy announced on Monday the closure would see the fishery fully protected until at least November 20. 
The news has been welcomed by many in the industry including chairman of PauaMAC3 Jason Ruawai, who said he was definitely in favour of the extension. 
Ruawai said he understood from the submissions that the majority were also in favour, however there was still a lot of work to do. 
READ MORE: * Public input called for on plans to extend Kaikoura shellfish ban 
"This is just the beginning. Now we've got a lot of research to do so we know what to do after November 20." 
Guy said the latest science information showed shellfish in the Kaikoura area had been badly impacted by the 7.8-magnitude earthquake, with 20 per cent of adult paua habitat being affected and an even greater impact on the juvenile paua habitat. 
"While some may be disappointed, I believe people understand the need to rebuild this fishery for the long term. We need to give the remaining adult paua and shellfish beds time to spawn, and the juveniles a chance to settle." 
The ministry would be working to develop a robust science package to estimate the impacts and provide sound advice for future management decisions, Guy said.
